title: A poor American in Ireland and Scotland /
author: Goodkind, Ben.
snippet: After about a two minutes' walk through Spittal street and past Castle Terrace street, I came upon the thoroughfare  that led up to the castle. It was a well paved street up which pedestrians as well as vehicles could go, for the incline was gradual.

title: A Tour in Tartan-Land
author: Bede, Cuthbert
snippet: MAKING our way from these evil memories and thetottering houses of the West Port, and keepingunder the Castle Terrace, we come upon the LothianRoad, which connects the old town with Princes Street. Here was formerly the Castle Barns, or Grange.

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: " I would not have minded, aunt, if he had told me of thatwretched contract before a certain night in April last—beforeI had seen Elsie Langton, in fact"—he continued, in a muchlower tone, with frequent pauses and breaks due to hesitation. " God help me, to see her was to love her, and from thatnight when first I saw her standing on the lonely landing inCastle Terrace, I knew that for better or worse no womanwould ever make me happy save Elsie Langton."

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance
author: Grant, James
snippet: The back of a narrow close, which was demolished inthe civil war of 1745, enclosed it on the east, and theSpur, with its strong rampart and twenty pieces of brasscannon, overlooked it on the north. There were thenno Castle Terrace or Western Approach to disfigure thecity on the south, and this green and verdant bankdescended smoothly and gradually downwards to thegreat market-place.

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: As he passed the end of Castle Terrace, the sound of a girl'svoice ejaculating, with half-suppressed sobs—
